title: BACH FLOWER REMEDIES: Overview, Uses, Side Effects, Precautions, Interactions, Dosing and Reviews
description: Learn more about BACH FLOWER REMEDIES uses, effectiveness, possible side effects, interactions, dosage, user ratings and products that contain BACH FLOWER REMEDIES.
cleaned_text: Overview Bach flower remedies are often so diluted that they contain little or no detectable amounts of active ingredients. Similar to homeopathic preparations, they aren't expected to have beneficial drug-like effects or safety concerns. There are 38 different remedies. People use Bach flower remedies for anxiety, [depression](https://www.webmd.com/depression/understanding-depression-basics), [ADHD](https://www.webmd.com/add-adhd/childhood-adhd/understanding-adhd-basics), pain, and many other conditions, but there is no good scientific evidence to support these uses. Don't confuse Bach flower remedies with homeopathy. Bach flower remedies are sometimes called homeopathic products because they are diluted like homeopathic remedies, but they aren't based on the same principles. Uses & Effectiveness Possibly Ineffective for - Anxiety. Taking Bach flower remedies doesn't seem to reduce anxiety. Side Effects [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/ss/slideshow-mouth-problems): Bach flower remedies are possibly safe when used in moderation. Since most Bach flower remedies contain little or no active ingredient, these products aren't expected to cause harm. But they are preserved in brandy and therefore contain alcohol. When applied to the [skin](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/picture-of-the-skin): There isn't enough reliable information to know if Bach flower remedies are safe or what the side effects might be. Since most Bach flower remedies contain little or no active ingredient, these products aren't expected to cause harm. Special Precautions and Warnings [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/ss/slideshow-mouth-problems): Bach flower remedies are possibly safe when used in moderation. Since most Bach flower remedies contain little or no active ingredient, these products aren't expected to cause harm. But they are preserved in brandy and therefore contain alcohol. When applied to the [skin](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/picture-of-the-skin): There isn't enough reliable information to know if Bach flower remedies are safe or what the side effects might be. Since most Bach flower remedies contain little or no active ingredient, these products aren't expected to cause harm. Pregnancy and breast-feeding: Bach flower remedies are likely unsafe when taken by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/rm-quiz-mouth-myths)while pregnant or breast-feeding because they contain alcohol. Alcohol can cause birth defects and other harm to infants. The alcohol in these preparations also passes into breast milk and can interfere with the infant's development. Interactions Disulfiram (Antabuse) interacts with BACH FLOWER REMEDIES Bach flower remedies contain alcohol. When disulfiram is taken within 12 hours of alcohol it can cause a reaction. Do not take Bach flower remedies if you are taking disulfiram. Major Interaction Do not take this combination Metronidazole (Flagyl) interacts with BACH FLOWER REMEDIES Bach flower remedies contain alcohol. When metronidazole is taken with alcohol it might cause a reaction. Talk to your health provider before taking Bach flower remedies if you are using metronidazole. Moderate Interaction Be cautious with this combination Dosing Similar to homeopathy, Bach flower remedies indicate how dilute they are by using specific letters and numbers. Dilutions of 1/10 are signified by "X." 1/100 are signified by "C." So, 1C = 1/100, 2C = 1/10,000, 3C = 1/1,000,000, and so on. Speak with a [healthcare](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics)provider before use.
